rows.title: Breathe to three

transcript.eng:
Close your eyes. 

Use the magic power of three to stay connected and relax.

Breathe in to the count of three. 1, 2, 3. 
Breathe out to the count of three. 1, 2, 3. 
Breathe in to the count of three. 1, 2, 3. 
Breathe out to the count of three. 1, 2, 3.

Do you feel any different? Deep breathing helps our whole body and mind to calm down. 

You are a star!

You are a star!

text_1.eng: Let’s take a moment for YOU. Looking after yourself well starts with noticing how you feel.

quiz_1_feedback_1.eng: Great! So good to hear you are in a positive space.

quiz_1_feedback_2.eng: Things are not always easy. But that is how we can grow and learn every day!

quiz_1_feedback_3.eng: Life can be hard. Whatever you are feeling, you can be proud of yourself for being here!

text_1_facilitator.eng:
Today's topic is about spending one-on-one time with our teens. 

Being a parent can be so hard. Sometimes it feels like our teens never listen to us.

But science shows that spending just a few minutes each day of focused one-on-one time with your teen helps build trust and love.

text_2.eng:
One-on-one time is when you focus on them, without TV or phones. Let them lead what you do or talk about.

It is great if you can do twenty minutes a day, but even five minutes a day is really good.

media_title.eng:
How will it help me and my family?  

Placeholder..

media_transcript.eng:
Hello.

Our topic today is one-on-one time with our children.

It is important to spend time with our children so that they can get to understand us, and for us to get an opportunity to understand them.

Remember, a family with good understanding lives in harmony.

text_1_facilitator.eng:
PLACEHOLDER TEXT

Anna, can we have some sort of intro to the testimonial..

media_title.eng:
Hear a caregiver's testimonial

Placeholder text - Anna - we need a title similar to the one above for row 1 (how will this help my family)..

media_transcript.eng:
When I first heard I had to spend One-on-One Time with my teen, it was hard for me. I did not know when to do it or what to say. I did not want to spoil my teen so that he thinks we have to do everything together.

But I really wanted to build my relationship with my teen and I wanted him to open up about what was troubling him. So we tried the One-on-One Time.

First, it felt weird, but it turned out to be fun! Now we watch his TV programme together and we chat about it. And we can even talk about how my son is changing into adolescence and even about girlfriends and those things!

rows.media_transcript:
When I first heard I had to spend One-on-One Time with my teen, it was hard for me. I did not know when to do it or what to say. I did not want to spoil my teen so that he thinks we have to do everything together.

But I really wanted to build my relationship with my teen and I wanted him to open up about what was troubling him. So we tried the One-on-One Time.

First, it felt weird, but it turned out to be fun! Now we watch his TV programme together and we chat about it. And we can even talk about how my son is changing into adolescence and even about girlfriends and those things!

text_1_facilitator.eng:
Let's think of ways to spend one-on-one time with your teen.

It may take some time to get used to one-on-one time, but the more you do it the better it gets!

You are an amazing parent for trying this.

quiz_1_question.eng: What could you do to spend one-on-one time with your teen?

quiz_1_feedback_1.eng:
Great idea! 

Feel like you have NO TIME and you are exhausted? Remember to also think of ways that do not take up extra time.

text_1_facilitator.eng: Here are this week’s takeaway skills!

section_1_text.eng:
Try to do it every day. 

Find 5 minutes (or more!) each day when your teen does not have something else they want to do.

section_2_text.eng:
Let your teen choose.

Tell your teen that you would like to spend some time with them and that they can choose what to do or talk about. They might think this is weird at first, but will come to enjoy this time with you!

section_3_text.eng:
Focus on your teen.

Switch off the TV and put phones aside. Look at your teen. Nod or say “I see” to show you are really paying attention. Accept what they say without judging them.

rows.text_1_facilitator: Here are this week’s takeaway skills!
rows.section_1_text:
Try to do it every day. 

Find 5 minutes (or more!) each day when your teen does not have something else they want to do.
rows.section_2_text:
Let your teen choose.

Tell your teen that you would like to spend some time with them and that they can choose what to do or talk about. They might think this is weird at first, but will come to enjoy this time with you!
rows.section_3_text:
Focus on your teen.

Switch off the TV and put phones aside. Look at your teen. Nod or say “I see” to show you are really paying attention. Accept what they say without judging them.

text_1_facilitator.eng: It can be a challenge to think of ways to spend one on one time with your teen!

text_2.eng:
Here are some ideas from other parents:

- Walk to the shops
- Get water together
- Do a chore together
- Prepare dinner
- Eat breakfast/lunch/dinner
- Have tea after school
- Watch a TV show
- Review homework
- Chat before bedtime
- Play a game/sport

Remember to use your new skills: DAY (Try to do it every day), PLAY (let your teen choose how to spend one on one time), and STAY (be focused on your teen)!

rows.text_1_facilitator: It can be a challenge to think of ways to spend one on one time with your teen!
rows.text_2:
Here are some ideas from other parents:

- Walk to the shops
- Get water together
- Do a chore together
- Prepare dinner
- Eat breakfast/lunch/dinner
- Have tea after school
- Watch a TV show
- Review homework
- Chat before bedtime
- Play a game/sport

Remember to use your new skills: DAY (Try to do it every day), PLAY (let your teen choose how to spend one on one time), and STAY (be focused on your teen)!

text_1_facilitator.eng:
Small actions, big results! Parents who practice their module skills at home get better results.

Spend 5-20 minutes of one-on-one time with your teen, every day you can this week.

quiz_1_question.eng: Can you spend 5-20 minutes of one-on-one time with your teen, every day that you can this week?

quiz_1_feedback_1.eng: That's great! Parents who spend focused one-on-one time with their teens can build trust and love!

quiz_1_feedback_2.eng: You can do it! Try spending just a few minutes each day with your teen. Remember that you can always think of ways do not take up extra time, like walking to the shop or preparing dinner together.

quiz_1_feedback_3.eng: That's okay. With time, spending focused time with your teen will become easier as you build a routine. At first, you can try to think of ways to spend time that do not take up extra time, like doing a chore togher.

text_1_facilitator.eng:
PLACEHOLDER TEXT

Anna, can we have some sort of outtro to module and connect it to the testimonial.. See the kids version.

media_title.eng:
Hear a teen's testimonial

Placeholder text: Anna, can you bring more context e.g., Hear how teens benefited etc.,

media_transcript.eng:
When my mother asked to spend time with me, I thought “Maybe something is wrong, maybe she is sick.” But she said “No, I just want to spend time.” I was sceptical, but I accepted.

She asked me what I like doing. It was strange and I was not comfortable, because she never ever spent time with me on my own.

The more she kept on trying and we spent this time together, it felt really nice. She got to share her own childhood with me, things I never heard before. That helped me to also share what is going on in my life. We even talk about boyfriends and about problems I have. I know I can talk to my mother now.

rows.media_transcript:
When my mother asked to spend time with me, I thought “Maybe something is wrong, maybe she is sick.” But she said “No, I just want to spend time.” I was sceptical, but I accepted.

She asked me what I like doing. It was strange and I was not comfortable, because she never ever spent time with me on my own.

The more she kept on trying and we spent this time together, it felt really nice. She got to share her own childhood with me, things I never heard before. That helped me to also share what is going on in my life. We even talk about boyfriends and about problems I have. I know I can talk to my mother now.
